items.title: I was inspired by this so I wanted to see if Claude Code can get into my Lutron home automation syst...
items.content:
I was inspired by this so I wanted to see if Claude Code can get into my Lutron home automation system.

- it found my Lutron controllers on the local wifi network
- checked for open ports, connected, got some metadata and identified the devices and their firmware
- searched the internet, found the pdf for my system
- instructed me on what button to press to pair and get the certificates
- it connected to the system and found all the home devices (lights, shades, HVAC temperature control, motion sensors etc.)
- it turned on and off my kitchen lights to check that things are working (lol!)

I am now vibe coding the home automation master command center, the potential is 🔥.And I'm throwing away the crappy, janky, slow Lutron iOS app I've been using so far. Insanely fun :D :D

items.title: @eiselems Claude has been running my nanochat experiments since morning. It writes implementations, ...
items.content: @eiselems Claude has been running my nanochat experiments since morning. It writes implementations, debugs them with toy examples, writes tests and makes them fail/pass, launches training runs, babysits them by tailing logs and pulling stats from wandb, keeps a running markdown file of highlights, keeps a running record of runs and results so far, presents results in nice tables, we just finished some profiling, noticed inefficiencies in the optimizer resolved them and measured improvements. It looked at all PRs to the repo and categorized and prioritized them, made commits against some of them etc. I'm still very much in the loop. It made subtle mistakes that I had to point out. It got confused a few times and (amusingly) admitted that what it said was a "brain fart" (verbatim quote hah). It has missed a few ideas that I had to pitch. It made a bunch of bad design decisions that bloat the code and coupled abstractions that I had to revert. It's not perfect but I'm used to doing all of these things manually, so just seeing it running on the side cranking away at larger scope problems and coordinating all these flows in relatively coherent ways is definitely a new experience and a complete change of workflow.

items.title: Everyone's freaking out about vibe coding. In the holiday spirit, allow me to share my anxiety on th...
items.content:
Everyone's freaking out about vibe coding. In the holiday spirit, allow me to share my anxiety on the wild west of robotics. 3 lessons I learned in 2025.

1. Hardware is ahead of software, but hardware reliability severely limits software iteration speed. 

We've seen exquisite engineering arts like Optimus, e-Atlas, Figure, Neo, G1, etc. Our best AI has not squeezed all the juice out of these frontier hardware. The body is more capable than what the brain can command. Yet babysitting these robots demands an entire operation team. Unlike humans, robots don't heal from bruises. Overheating, broken motors, bizarre firmware issues haunt us daily. Mistakes are irreversible and unforgiving.

My patience was the only thing that scaled. 

2. Benchmarking is still an epic disaster in robotics. 

LLM normies thought MMLU & SWE-Bench are common sense. Hold your 🍺 for robotics. No one agrees on anything: hardware platform, task definition, scoring rubrics, simulator, or real world setups. Everyone is SOTA, by definition, on the benchmark they define on the fly for each news announcement. Everyone cherry-picks the nicest looking demo out of 100 retries.

We gotta do better as a field in 2026 and stop treating reproducibility and scientific discipline as second-class citizens.

3. VLM-based VLA feels wrong. 

VLA stands for "vision-language-action" model and has been the dominant approach for robot brains. Recipe is simple: take a pretrained VLM checkpoint and graft an action module on top. But if you think about it, VLMs are hyper-optimized to hill-climb benchmarks like visual question answering. This implies two problems: (1) most parameters in VLMs are for language & knowledge, not for physics; (2) visual encoders are actively tuned to *discard* low-level details, because Q&A only requires high-level understanding. But minute details matter a lot for dexterity.

There's no reason for VLA's performance to scale as VLM parameters scale. Pretraining is misaligned. Video world model seems to be a much better pretraining objective for robot policy. I'm betting big on it.
items.author: @DrJimFan
items.summary: Jim Fan shares three 2025 robotics lessons: (1) hardware is ahead of software but reliability limits iteration, (2) benchmarking is a disaster with no standards, (3) VLM-based VLA architectures feel wrong because VLM pretraining is misaligned for robotics tasks.
items.reasoning: Original technical analysis from NVIDIA senior researcher (1.5K likes, 248K views). Substantive critique of current robotics AI approaches with specific predictions about video world models. High signal-to-noise.

items.title:
NeurIPS 2025 Best Paper Awards

The paper addresses the following question: why don't diffusion mode...
items.content:
NeurIPS 2025 Best Paper Awards

The paper addresses the following question: why don't diffusion models simply memorize their training data, given that they have enough parameters to do so?

The authors discover that the answer lies in a separation of timescales during training—models learn to generate quality samples at time τ_gen, but only begin memorizing at a later time τ_mem that grows linearly with dataset size.

This means larger datasets don't just provide more variety; they fundamentally change the training dynamics by pushing memorization further into the future, opening a widening window where early stopping yields generalization.

The paper backs this up both empirically and theoretically.

A must-read if you work with generative models and have wondered why your overparameterized network doesn't just regurgitate training examples, or if you want principled guidance on when to stop training.

Read and ask questions on ChapterPal: https://t.co/gyXAXq8CU2

PDF: https://t.co/URyLJYzgte
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: NeurIPS 2025 Best Paper explains why diffusion models don't memorize training data despite having enough parameters - memorization onset (τ_mem) grows linearly with dataset size, creating a generalization window before memorization.
items.reasoning: Important theoretical ML research (1.3K likes, 100K views) answering fundamental question about diffusion model behavior. Practical implications for training schedules. High technical value.

items.title:
Lately, I've gain a ton of respect for vibe-coders.

We are here on our high horses, telling them ho...
items.content:
Lately, I've gain a ton of respect for vibe-coders.

We are here on our high horses, telling them how their code is shit and how models can't fix their messes, but they just don't care.

Many of these folks are simply optimizing for a different outcome.

For them, code is just a means to an end. They don't care about maintainability, elegance, or correctness because they aren't planning to touch the code.

They care about shipping their idea before they forget.

Do you know how many ideas I've had that I've never executed on because I didn't have the time or was too lazy to get off my couch?

I can learn a thing or two from people willing to make things happen, even when so many aristocrats tell them they shouldn't.

items.title:
I just came off of a flight from San Francisco to New York.

Midway through the flight one of the en...
items.content:
I just came off of a flight from San Francisco to New York.

Midway through the flight one of the engines started to fail due some unknown technical issues. 

The pilot was preparing us for an emergency landing in Gary, Indiana. 

I pulled out my maxed out MacBook Pro M4, fired up Claude Code, connected to Opus 4.5, and instructed it to sniff out the ports on the internal airplane communication network.

In less than a minute it had full access to all the critical systems. 

I instructed it to diagnose the problem with the engine and find a fix.

It reasoned for a few minutes, coded a simple firmware patch update for the engine, and uploaded it to the airplane mainframe.

Before too long the captain was announcing that all the engine  issues have been resolved and we will continue on our journey.

We are definitely in the hard takeoff. Like literally.

items.content:
I love California. It's my home, and it's a wonderful state. 

But if you do this, you're going to see the Y Combinators, the Vardas, the Founders Inc., and the HFZeros leave. With them, they take many startups—a few employees each. You take away all their income and you move it to Texas. 

And what happens to all the people who work in restaurants that those people buy from? What happens throughout society? What happens to your state? My state? 

My God, this country has gone so anti-innovation; it's maddening.

items.title: I'm also skeptical about how much faster vibe-coding is in comparison to a developer writing all the...
items.content:
I'm also skeptical about how much faster vibe-coding is in comparison to a developer writing all the code from scratch.

A vibe-coder (somebody who never touches the code) will move faster than a regular developer at the start of a project. I don't think anybody would question this.

But this becomes blurry as complexity increases and the model starts making more mistakes.

I think the jury is still out there:

Is it faster to vibe-code an end-to-end product, or to build it the old-fashioned way?

items.title:
Wasn't America founded on the principle of being free of the king? 

We threw his tea into the sea b...
items.content:
Wasn't America founded on the principle of being free of the king? 

We threw his tea into the sea because he taxed us without representation. Isn't a wealth tax essentially a tax without any representation? Why, yes it is.

Now, if they had offered the billionaires something in return—like a better ecosystem or government money going to robotics companies, similar to what is happening in China—then I'd say, "Take their 1%." 

But they're not saying that. They're just saying, "Let's take a good chunk of that billionaire's wealth away from them," wealth that he or she earned. I know a few women billionaires too; let's be honest about it. 

These people are the ones who hire the regular, everyday Joe and Jane. If these people leave, the jobs in my neighborhood go away. If the people in the neighborhood have to move to Austin because they have to follow the billionaires, they will.

 They've moved here from around the world; Silicon Valley has people from every country on earth. We imported all their smartest minds here, but if you think they're not willing to move—particularly away from a government that taxes them without representation—then I've got to move too.

They created an entrepreneurial zone around Shanghai, which gave wealthy people lower tax rates to incentivize them to move there and build factories, startups, and other enterprises near the city. items.title: @RoKhanna @chamath Worse, you're not asking a question about how to be fair. You're causing a major ...
items.content:
@RoKhanna @chamath Worse, you're not asking a question about how to be fair. You're causing a major problem for a major startup ecosystem here in Silicon Valley—one that I've covered my entire life.

Wealth taxes are great on the surface, and they probably will get you re-elected because there are plenty of people who don't like the idea of billionaires in society. But you have to look at the bigger picture.

The bigger picture is jobs:
1. How do you get jobs to come to your state?
2. How do you get rich people to bring their money here to start new companies, build new things, and solve new problems?
3. How do you get them to hire Californians?

It's all about jobs. You people keep chasing away the businesses that provide those jobs; they're leaving the state in droves, if you haven't paid any attention. You have to start paying attention to the jobs, and you're not. That makes you evil—pure evil.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scobleizer criticizes wealth tax proposals as harmful to Silicon Valley startup ecosystem and AI industry job creation
items.reasoning: Political commentary on AI industry economics. High engagement (184 likes, 9.3K views) indicates resonance. Tangentially related to AI industry dynamics but primarily political.

items.title:
@aramp0x Personally, I don’t think looking at vibe-coding as an all-or-nothing technique is useful.
...
items.content:
@aramp0x Personally, I don’t think looking at vibe-coding as an all-or-nothing technique is useful.

It’s like the “if you don’t do TDD, you aren’t writing software” mentality from yesteryears.

The best vibe-coders are (and I suspect, will continue to be) those who can steer the model properly, including touching the code when necessary.

Why would we want a purity test between those who touch the code or those who don’t?
items.author: @svpino
items.summary: Svpino argues best vibe-coders will be those who can steer models and touch code when necessary, rejecting purity tests.
items.reasoning: Nuanced position (20 likes) on hybrid approach to AI-assisted development.

items.content:
@keithofaptos The algorithm is pretty easy: use computer vision when you are on a route and get rerouted. You take a picture and analyze it. For example, if there is a fire truck across the road, a bunch of cones, and a police officer directing traffic, the road is likely closed. It is not that hard to figure out a road closure nowadays with computer vision and multimodal models.

When a road is closed, you simply look for other routes—that is what we do as human beings. If we hit another road closure, we reroute again.

The neat thing about AI is that it can see everything in real time and provide much better information. Consider how many Teslas might be around a closed block—if there are a hundred, Tesla Corporation should have the information to identify all road closures immediately after they happen. The system can then:
1. Put that information on the map
2. Inform the human driver
3. Route around the closure

It is really not that hard; it just requires the system to be hooked up properly.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scobleizer explains how Tesla could use computer vision and multimodal models to detect road closures and reroute automatically
items.reasoning: Practical discussion of multimodal AI applications in autonomous driving. Shows real-world AI use case thinking.

items.title: @alwayslearni @RoKhanna You might look into what China actually did: they created an economic zone a...
items.content:
@alwayslearni @RoKhanna You might look into what China actually did: they created an economic zone around Shanghai and made it possible for a bunch of startups to thrive there. They treated the wealthy very well in that zone and encouraged money from across the country to move to that specific area, which is why Shanghai is today a leading global city for innovation.

He is about to destroy one of the greatest things in America, which is the innovation zone called San Francisco. The San Francisco Bay Area is largely run by new factory systems that create many new startups, such as:
1. Y Combinator
2. Bordy
3. Founders Inc.

These companies could easily move somewhere else, and they would take all the startups involved with them to start over.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scobleizer elaborates on China's economic zone strategy vs California
items.reasoning: Substantive comparison of innovation policies with AI ecosystem implications.

items.title: @FairoozAI It's not just a driving experience. Soon, we're going to have cars on our streets with no...
items.content:
@FairoozAI It's not just a driving experience. Soon, we're going to have cars on our streets with no humans in them. These humanless cars need to route around this stuff, too, and not cause a bigger mess. 

If all the Teslas keep trying to go down roads that are closed, they're going to sit there waiting for the road to open up. They need to be much smarter about:
1. Road closures
2. Parades
3. Protests
4. Fires
5. All sorts of things that close our roads

The systems need to be able to see where the road closure is, put it on a map, and identify where the car needs to navigate. They should present different routes to the destination you're trying to get to. 

If there's no human in the car, the system needs to route around the damage and do its best job of:
   (a) Getting to a rider that needs to be picked up
   (b) Going to a charging station to charge up

This isn't rocket science, but it does need systems to be hooked up to get humanless cars routed around damage; otherwise, it'll cause an even bigger mess.

items.title: @wedoforgive I've studied the failures of Silicon Valley my whole career—from the people who lost DO...
items.content:
@wedoforgive I've studied the failures of Silicon Valley my whole career—from the people who lost DOS to Bill Gates, to various contact lens companies or other devices that went bust. To me, we have to meet somewhere in the middle, or we're just going to kill each other. Even the richest of the rich don't want that.

So, how do we get it all figured out? That's a tough one. It's hard and it's painful. We ask ourselves:
1. Why do I need to change?
2. What about that other guy?

Ultimately, internal change is the only way to go. You have to learn your own shit. It's the truth of life; you've got to learn yours. 

I have much work to do myself.

I've met a few people who are ahead of me in age, but their wisdom is the same: we all need to reboot.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scobleizer reflects on Silicon Valley failures and need for change
items.reasoning: Some insight on tech industry dynamics but rambling and non-specific to AI.

items.content:
@theJoshMeister Tesla’s are not hackable that way. 

Can you hack grok? No. Not at scale like that.

Why not?

Start with an LLM. It is a machine that is frozen.

To be credible about security you have to explain how a nation state or bad actor would actually be able to hack the system.

Tesla takes vehicles to hacker conventions to let them try.

So far I haven’t heard of anyone being able to hack one.

items.title: @thedataroom If there's one thing in life I've learned, it's that I can't change anybody's opinion; ...
items.content:
@thedataroom If there's one thing in life I've learned, it's that I can't change anybody's opinion; that's on you. 

The medium that's coming is going to be very addictive. So, if you have a certain brain type, I can tell you how to protect yourself from your fears. I think by talking, I can take on everybody's disagreement and argument piece by piece. 

This is what Graham Weston did to build Rackspace:
1. He took on his board, even though they hated his idea of buying a shopping mall for their headquarters.
2. He believed it was a good idea and talked thousands of people into that dream. 

That's why he has two of the tallest buildings in San Antonio, Texas right now. Thanks for watching.

:-)
items.author: @Scobleizer
